captions.text:
SHANE SMITH: The next stop on
our tour of North Korean

boredom and propaganda was the
Great People's Library, which

is this massive library
that they're very,
very excited about.

And they make you walk the
whole god damn thing.

And the first thing you learn
is that Kim Jong Il invented

the best, most perfect reading
desk because you can alter the
level of the desk.

SHANE SMITH: Kim Jong
Il invented it.
And it's the best desk ever.
And you're like, OK.
It's a table with--
You can move a level.
It's like a simple table.

Then they take you to the
philosopher hotline, which I

found pretty interesting,
which is if you have a

philosophical, Marxist,
dialectic problem, then you

can come to the library and
ask the philosopher god.
SHANE SMITH: And that's it.
Thank you.

The other thing I found amazing
is they're very proud
of their modern music library.
They've got the Beatles.

And they've got Bob
Dylan and stuff.

But the music room was
completely empty.

And I started thinking
about why they have
this kind of place.

It seemed to me that it was used
for maybe upper echelons,

or party officials, or guides,
or wannabe guards to learn

idiomatic speech so that they'll
understand what we say
when we talk in vernacular.

And so you can picture them with
headphones on listening,
going, "Abbey Road.

I understand those
bastards now."

SHANE SMITH: They made us get
up at 6:00 in the morning.
We get put in the truck.
And we just drive.
We drove for four hours.

And when we get out,
we're at the sea.

And there's this huge thing,
which is called a barrage.

I didn't know what
a barrage was.
But it's basically a huge dam.

And they've dammed up
the Taedong River.

And it's just a triumph
of the will.

And oh my god, it's the
biggest, greatest
thing we ever did.

And now it's being blamed for
the huge floods that they have

and the famine, because
of the floods.

And it's destroyed all their
rice growing crops, which they

don't have much of because it's
a mountainous country.

They ended up destroying
all the arable land
that they had left.

JAMIE: You don't want him
to stand in front
of the Great Leader?

SHANE SMITH: Don't
block the shot.
OK.
JAMIE: OK.

SHANE SMITH: I'm going
to stand to the side.

JAMIE: Shane, don't stand in
front of the Dear Leader
because you're blocking him.
SHANE SMITH: OK.

But they're so freaked out about
the barrage, that we

were filming it, which
is why he brought us
out there, I thought.

And they're like, film
it anything more,
you're going to jail.

Don't stand in front
of the Dear Leader.

Our political guard-- who we had
nicknamed Speedy Gonzales

because he looked like a little
zippy guy, and he was
always everywhere--

started to really
get mad at us.

We've just been told not to
stand in front of the picture
of Kim Jong Il.

Actually, Speedy Gonzales, our
guard who hates us shooting,
just saw us.
And he's not letting us shoot.

So I'm just going to talk
about the barrage.
It's beautiful.
It's nice.

And he's looking at
us right now.
It's freaking me out.

He's threatened Jamie, who's
shooting this, with criminal

action, which means to go
to jail here, which
would not be enjoyable.

He's looking at me now, so we're
going to walk over here,

check out the thing
and pretend like
we're shooting something.

They had had enough of
us by this point.

At this point, we started
to get really scared.
They're like, you know what?

Stop filming, stop shooting
anything.
It's totally insane.
One more day.

I keep telling myself,
one more day.

SHANE SMITH: One of the fun/sad
times is they took us
to a school.

And it's a school for the best
and brightest, the prodigies.

And you go there, and you see
how great the students are.

And here it's just kids in
uniforms being incredibly

amazing and much better than
we are, of course, at
everything.

So the best needlepointers
are needlepointing away.

And the best guitar players
are playing.

Accordion players, pianists,
the best at
computer graphics, whatever.

They have people for
enunciation.

There's one kid playing
guitar.
Amazing.

The guitar was bigger
than him.

And again you're like, oh
these great kids and
everything.

But it's so sad and so scary
because they've been picked

out and like, you will
learn for the state.

And they're learning
and learning and
learning for the state.
And then there's a show.

We're going to an art
performance now with the kids.

And then we give the flower
after the performance.

After the performance, we
give it to the kids.

FEMALE SPEAKER 1:
[SPEAKING KOREAN]
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[APPLAUSE]

SHANE SMITH: You realize
everything in this country is
for Kim Jong Il.
Kim Jong Il likes shows.
He likes Broadway.
He likes musicals.

These kids are just press-ganged
into service for

the state to provide shows for
the two tourists who are there
at any given time.

And this times a billion is what
we were about to see with
Arirang Games.
SHANE SMITH: Got my ticket.

This is the waiting
room before we go
upstairs to the games.

But it's, as you can see, a
very busy, bustling place.

The only reason why any tourists
are allowed into

North Korea is because of what
you're about to see.

The Arirang Games, or the famous
mass gymnastics, are

120,000 people who work for
about two years to do this

incredibly elaborate
choreographed Andrew Lloyd

Webber extravaganza,
but on acid.

You're sitting on a dais
reserved for Kim Jong Il.

And you see the most insane
thing you've ever
seen in your life.

It's a history of the Korean
Revolution as portrayed by

120,000 people doing a
simultaneous pantomime.

Kim Jong Il likes a
spectacle, man.

And this is the biggest
spectacle in the world.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[CHANTING IN UNISON]

SHANE SMITH: We just go back
from the Mass Games.

And now we're at
the restaurant.

And they have seasoned dog,
smothered ox rib, which I
guess wouldn't be bad.
And then that's about it.

But as you can see, it's
not bustling here.

It was nuts at the games,
because I was sitting there.

We were sitting right where
Madeleine Albright was at and

right where Kim Jong
Il sits and Ike.

We're sitting here
just for us.
Everyone's clapping.

Everyone's doing everything
for us.

You just sit there, and
you feel like God.

Or you'd feel like God
if you'd slept.

We haven't slept in about three
days, so I have a beer.
It was our last night.

So we went out for our last
night karaoke fest, as you do.
[KOREAN].

FEMALE SINGERS:
[SINGING KOREAN SONG]

SHANE SMITH: Well what was
interesting was it was a South
Korean machine.

And it had some programmed songs
it it, Western songs.
[SINGING "ANARCHY IN THE UK"]

At first they thought, oh he's
just drunk, making a mockery
of a military song.

And they didn't know how
to deal with it.

The women didn't know
how to deal with it.

They have no cultural references
whatsoever.
[SINGING "ANARCHY IN THE UK"]

So when I finished singing,
they're all looking
at me like I'm crazy.

And I realize, they don't
know what punk rock is.

Not only do they not
have rock and roll,
they didn't have jazz.

They didn't have
fucking blues.

They never had any
of this shit.

There are no cultural
similarities whatsoever.

FEMALE SINGERS:
[SINGING KOREAN SONG]

SHANE SMITH: Sometimes I imagine
if someone coming from

the cowboy times-- like someone
who comes in a time

machine or frozen in
ice or something--

and you have to explain to
them what an airplane is.

Or you have to explain what
supermarkets are.

And this is as close
as you get to that.
This is a time machine.

This is 1930s Russia or
1950s Soviet Union.

So they see me as the Yankee
imperialist aggressor.

And I see them as the land
that time forgot.

FEMALE SPEAKER 2: --by the Great
Leader Kim Jong Il for

the course modeling the entire
army on the [INAUDIBLE] idea

were displayed at the Korean
Revolution Museum.

Leader Kim Jong Il put forward
as the general task of army

building to turn the People's
Army into the army of the

leader and the party by
modelling the entire army--

comments.text:
This guy is an embarassment. Yes I hate North Korea we all do for their 
gorvernment...But the people there seem to be happy and enthusiasic, 
performing and very talened...North Korea wants to show its merits, and its 
just a lack of respect to make fun of those unsuspecting people and their 
culture...YES obviously the lack of freedom and knowledge in N Korea is 
bad, the leader and government need to be overturned, but these people do 
not deserve this humiliation. I would be polite and applaud and smile and 
try to bring to their lives a little bit of joy, I would sing them a rock 
song but NOT in a horrid voice and an attitude that says "f--- you".﻿

government, they are tormented by the government but at the same time they 
are influenced by it, and live thier lives entusiastically in a more 
traditional way than we do...No TV, no modern music...and yet they sing and 
perform so beautifully, in a way it is like they are happier than us...Yes 
the country needs to be reunited and overcome this government, but the 
people deserve credit for their talents and efforts and RESPECT when you go 
to their land.

comments.author: caitlin brantley

comments.text:
Anarchy inside NK! Yeah, the Tea Girl's predicament is bleak, but the 
Pistols' karaoke session was the crux of doc for me. Brief and 
surface-silly, yet glaringly meaningful.  These poor grunts of the Great 
Bleeders wouldn't know how to reclaim their inner-anarchists even if passed 
to them on  punkrock platters! Generations of psy-op indoctrination, 
group-think, leader-worship, other-aversion, and terror tactics, make for 
an uncomfortable moment when Host Dude breaks into his comic cover of what 
one would think would be the LAST number to ever show up on the set-list 
during this clockwork-choreographed tumble down the tourist rabbit hole. 
I'm glad it did, it made my day, but how did that happen, anyway? 
Somebody's goin' to the gulag for that one, guaranteed. He does his best to 
get the locals to join in, but cannot bridge the ideological gap. What does 
one do when suddenly confronted with a Western World Monster of Anarchic 
Abandon and Free Will? Revert back to the safe softness of robotic 
synchronous swaying, of course! The Supreme Leaders' portraits see all, 
after all. Nice try, Mr. Host. Funny as Hell, but a subversive fail, 
nonetheless. These folks are too scared to break character and cut loose.﻿

comments.text:
jesus christ... i can't help but wonder what the suicide rate is in North 
Korea. what a bleak, abysmal place. i mean, i know the world and life 
itself can be inherently bleak and all that stuff, but just... holy fucking 
shit. i cannot fathom daily existence in a such a place as NK. it's gotta 
be so demoralizing and  soul-crushing, even way more so than life for us 
Western wage drones. no wonder the people there are such frightened sheep. 
they've had all of their spirit turned to gray mush over the span of 
generations by their shitty "Supreme Leaders."﻿
comments.author: MegaLysergic

with extra-strong LSD. i'll get some popcorn and watch that show.
comments.author: MegaLysergic

comments.text:
+MegaLysergic Its really strange, I used to think what you think, but after 
seeing this documentary, it seems that the people of N Korea have been SO 
successfully manipulated, they actually ENJOY what they are doing and 
approach it with enthusiasm and great spirit. In a way, they are humans at 
their very best but doing it for the wrong reasons and not realizing they 
are doing it for the wrong reasons. 

Their lives are simple : no cellphones, computers, 
commercialization...There must be a bliss somewhere in this 
ignorance...They definitely need to open their eyes and start a revolution 
and overturn their government...They are great patriotic people and need to 
channel their energy into something a LOT more real and positive. 


The thing is, they need to do it themselves... No one can go in and take 
out their government...if they do, it will only confirm that others are 
horrible imperialists who have ruined their wonderful Supreme government, 
create uprisings and poverty...We need to find a way to REACH OUT to these 
people and INFORM them of the abuses being practiced on them, the 
limits...And give them a means to come together and defeat this government. 


Even Kim Jong Un and his friends cannot hold up against millions of 
civilians who have been enlightened.
comments.author: Katie K.

they are happy and everything, but you can just see the heart-wrenching

exist.﻿

comments.author: The Wacko Bros

comments.text:
For all the people who are saying that the US and North Korea are the 
same... You know what, fuck you. Im sorry. Personally, I dont like America 
very much, and I actually want to move to SOUTH Korea, but how dare you 
watch this and think that this is just like America?
Worshipping God is NOTHING like what these people have to do to the Kim 
family. They are literally forced to cry when they die, they have pictures 
of them in their homes, and they have to travel far just to pretend to 
dance as happily as they can for them. 
Being told to say the Pledge of Allegiance here is a bullshit comparison! 
Its just a sign of respect, North Koreans have to literally treat this guy 
BETTER than they would their own father. 
Yes, in our society, we are told what to think. If you dont wear this kind 
of clothes, youre poor, blah blah blah. But do you realize that over there, 
if you say something bad about your country, THEY PUT YOU IN JAIL?! Thats 
not even comparable to here! Our "punishment" is bitchy teenagers, this is 
THE GOVERNMENT!!
Well, this is the longest comment I've ever written. But seriously, fuck 
you. The lives these people lead are unimaginable. As much as I dont like 
America... Its not even on the same level as this. And anyone who thinks 
differently is an ignorant asshole who doesnt know what theyre talking

comments.author: Toney Huang

comments.text:
Goddamn.
I born in Belarus, it's like a post-soviet country and there are lots of 
shit was happenning 30-40 years ago.
My parents told me that there was a Party which was ordering everyone what 
to do and how to live.
If you were trying to resist you'd end up in loneliness, you won't be able 
to get a job, education, medicine.

The worst thing if you were an orphan, they could make a new first and last 
name for you, 
you could be a part of some kinda crazy soviet experiment called "an ideal 
soviet man" or something.

I'm not trying to say that nowayads are great, against most of people were 
OK with this,
because you didn't have any responsibility for your life, you wasn't need 
to take risks or something.
IMO now we have much more chances for a good life.﻿
